stories.text:
Try this little experiment,

We start by acknowledging that this page exists:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_S%26P_500_companies_by_carbon_footprint

The title is "List of S&P 500 companies by carbon footprint" and it's hosted on wikipedia, which should have the best possible SEO score ever. It's been there since January so it should have been indexed already by Google.

Now try searching for: list of s&p 500 companies by carbon footprint,

I get 15,900,000 results (!) but only two pages of them (what?), none of them is the page we are looking for.

Let's be more specific and search for: list of s&p 500 companies by carbon footprint wikipedia,

52 results total, none of them are the page we are looking for, we do get "List of countries by carbon dioxides emissions", though, which is page that nowhere in its content mentions "S&P" or "carbon footprint" ... thanks I guess.

Let's be very specific and search for: "list of s&p 500 companies by carbon footprint" (in quotes, verbatim),

I get back two results,

The first one is a from a clone of wikipedia (of the page we are looking for, at least) that is somehow ranked ABOVE wikipedia.org ...

The second one is from wikipedia, "Category:List of companies", it is a page where the page I'm looking for is referenced,

And that's it ...
stories.title: Show HN: How bad Google Search has become
